put in.translation[0].definitions[0].def: to fix a piece of equipment somewhere and connect it so that it is ready to be used
put in.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: We decided to have a new bathroom put in.
put in.translation[0].definitions[1].def: to spend time or use energy working or practising something
put in.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: Dorothy had put in a lot of hard work during her six years as chairperson.
put in.translation[0].definitions[2].def: to interrupt someone in order to say something
put in.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: ‘How old are you?’ ‘Sixteen.’ ‘I’m sixteen too, ’ put in Dixie.
put in.translation[0].definitions[3].def: to ask for something in an official way
put in.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: She put in an insurance claim.
We must put in an order by tonight.
I put in for a pay increase.
put in.translation[0].definitions[4].def: to trust someone or something or believe that they can do something
put in.translation[0].definitions[4].exa: I’m putting my faith in the appeal judges.
put in.translation[0].definitions[5].def: to do something in a particular way, especially a performance in a play, film, race etc
put in.translation[0].definitions[5].exa: He put in a brilliant performance in the British Grand Prix.
put in.translation[0].definitions[6].def: to go to a social event, meeting etc for a short time
put in.translation[0].definitions[6].exa: There was an hour yet before she needed to put in an appearance at the restaurant.
put in.translation[0].definitions[7].def: if a ship puts in, it enters a port
put in.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to officially make a claim, request etc to buy something, do something etc
put in.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: Other unions immediately put in similar wage claims.
Various companies have put in bids for the business.
